commits.message: feat(feature): add comprehensive layered feature toggle system

wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the overall kratos-boilerplate system. Explain its purpose as a production-ready microservice boilerplate with authentication, security, and extensibility features. Describe the high-level architecture including the separation between backend Go services using Kratos framework and the frontend Vue.js application. Document the technology stack, including Go, Vue.js, PostgreSQL, Redis, and gRPC. Illustrate the relationship between major components: API layer, service layer, business logic, data access, and frontend. Include a conceptual diagram showing system boundaries, data flow, and integration points. Provide context on use cases such as user management, secure authentication, and plugin extensibility. Make this accessible to new developers while providing enough depth for architects evaluating the system.

wiki_catalogs.name: Clean Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Clean Architecture implementation in kratos-boilerplate. Detail the four-layer structure: API, Service, Biz, and Data layers. Explain the responsibility of each layer—Service for API contract implementation, Biz for business use cases, Data for persistence, and Server for transport. Document dependency rules (dependencies flow inward), inversion of control, and how interfaces are defined in higher layers and implemented in lower ones. Illustrate request flow from HTTP/gRPC endpoint through middleware, service, biz, to data layer. Include examples from auth.go files across layers to show invocation relationships. Address how this design enhances testability with isolated unit tests and supports maintainability through loose coupling.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Service
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Authentication Service in kratos-boilerplate. Thoroughly explain user registration, login, logout, session management, and token refresh mechanisms. Document the implementation flow across service, biz, and data layers, including interface definitions, domain models (User, JWT tokens), and error handling patterns. Include concrete examples from auth.go files showing request validation, password hashing, and token generation. Explain integration with the API layer via auth.proto and middleware for authentication enhancement. Address common issues such as failed logins, account locking, token expiration, and CSRF protection. Provide guidance on extending authentication with third-party providers through provider.go.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the Authentication API defined in auth.proto. Document all endpoints including User Register, User Login, Refresh Token, and Logout. For each endpoint, specify HTTP methods, URL patterns, request/response schemas in both JSON and gRPC formats. Explain the use of google.api.http annotations for RESTful mapping and validate.proto for input validation. Detail authentication mechanisms using JWT tokens, including token generation, expiration, and refresh flow. Include error handling with error_reason.proto codes and HTTP status mappings. Provide concrete request/response examples for successful and error scenarios. Explain integration with captcha and rate limiting. Document security considerations such as password hashing, session management, and protection against common attacks (e.g., brute force, CSRF). Include client implementation examples in Go and TypeScript.

wiki_catalogs.name: Plugin Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Plugin Manager component in kratos-boilerplate. Explain how the PluginManager discovers, loads, initializes, and manages the lifecycle of plugins from the plugins/ directory. Document the role of PluginRegistry in maintaining plugin metadata and state, and how Wire is used for dependency injection into plugins. Include concrete examples from plugin_manager.go showing startup sequence, error handling during loading, and integration with the main application. Describe the plugin interface contract defined in interfaces.go and how plugins register themselves. Address common issues such as failed plugin initialization, duplicate plugin IDs, and dependency resolution. Provide guidance on implementing custom plugins that conform to the expected lifecycle and interface.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the Vue.js component architecture in kratos-boilerplate. Describe the structure and responsibilities of top-level views (Home, Login, Register) and reusable components (HelloWorld). Explain the composition pattern between parent App.vue and child components. Document the styling approach using style.css, including CSS scope, class naming, and responsive layout techniques. Provide examples of component props, slots, and events usage. Include guidance on creating new components, ensuring accessibility, and maintaining consistent UI/UX patterns. Address common issues such as style conflicts, component communication, and performance optimization for re-rendering.

wiki_catalogs.name: Database Schema
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the core database schema in the kratos-boilerplate application. Detail the 'users' table structure including fields such as id, username, email, password_hash, status, and timestamps, specifying data types, constraints, and indexes. Document the 'data_keys' table used by the KMS system, including key_id, root_key_id, encrypted_data_key, and creation metadata. Explain entity relationships, primary keys, and any foreign key constraints. Include sample SQL queries for common operations like user lookup and key retrieval. Describe the data access patterns implemented in the Data layer using the repository pattern, and illustrate how business logic interacts with these models. Address data validation rules, uniqueness constraints, and security considerations for storing sensitive information like password hashes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Flow Security
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the authentication security mechanisms in kratos-boilerplate. Detail the JWT-based authentication flow including token generation, signature validation, expiration policies, and secure refresh token handling. Explain how the system prevents common vulnerabilities such as brute force attacks, session fixation, and token leakage. Document the integration between the auth service, business logic, and data layer for secure credential verification and user state management. Include configuration options from config.yaml that affect authentication security like token TTL, refresh window, and rate limiting. Provide code examples showing secure token issuance and validation patterns. Address best practices for HTTPS enforcement, secure cookie settings, and CORS policies in production deployments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Unit Testing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for unit testing in kratos-boilerplate. Explain the purpose and scope of unit tests within the clean architecture, focusing on isolated component validation in the internal/ packages. Document testing patterns used in auth_test.go and captcha_test.go, including table-driven tests, error path verification, and method coverage. Include examples of test setup and assertion strategies using Go's testing package. Describe how unit tests validate business logic in biz/, data access in data/, and service layer contracts in service/. Address mocking techniques for dependencies using minimal interface mocks, and explain how test files are co-located with implementation. Provide guidance on writing effective unit tests, achieving high code coverage, and debugging test failures. Mention integration with go test and Makefile targets.

wiki_catalogs.name: Main Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the main configuration system in kratos-boilerplate. Explain the structure of config.yaml as defined by conf.proto, detailing each configuration section including server, database, redis, jwt, captcha, and logging. Document how the Kratos configuration loader parses and validates the protobuf-based configuration at startup. Provide examples of valid configuration entries for different environments and explain the purpose of each field. Include guidance on how to extend the configuration schema using conf.proto for custom features. Address common issues such as malformed YAML, invalid values, and missing required fields, with troubleshooting steps and validation techniques.

wiki_catalogs.name: Docker Setup
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Docker setup in kratos-boilerplate. Explain the structure and purpose of the Dockerfile, including multi-stage builds, base images, Go compilation, and artifact copying. Detail how the Makefile integrates with Docker through build, run, and release targets. Document best practices for building optimized container images, minimizing attack surface, and ensuring reproducibility. Include examples of customizing the build for different environments, leveraging build arguments, and integrating with CI/CD pipelines. Address common issues such as dependency caching, cross-platform builds, and debugging containerized applications.

wiki_catalogs.name: Adding New Features
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for adding new features to the kratos-boilerplate. Explain the end-to-end workflow starting from defining a new use case in the biz layer (biz.go), implementing business logic in internal/biz/, adding data access methods in internal/data/, and exposing functionality through internal/service/. Use concrete examples such as extending the authentication system with multi-factor authentication. Document how to maintain Clean Architecture boundaries, ensure dependency rules are followed, and register new components via Wire (wire_gen.go). Include guidance on keeping business logic pure and testable, and demonstrate integration with existing services. Address common pitfalls like circular dependencies and improper layer violations, and provide debugging tips when feature registration fails.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Register
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed API documentation for the User Register endpoint. Specify the HTTP POST method and gRPC method signature, including request body fields (username, password, email, captcha_token) and validation rules enforced by validate.proto. Document the google.api.http annotation mapping to RESTful /auth/v1/register. Explain password hashing using crypto package, captcha verification integration, and user creation flow through biz and data layers. Include success response with user ID and error cases such as duplicate email, weak password, invalid captcha, with corresponding error_reason codes and HTTP status codes (400, 409). Provide JSON and protobuf request/response examples. Detail security practices including rate limiting, protection against enumeration attacks, and secure error messaging. Include a Go client example using gRPC and a TypeScript fetch example for the HTTP endpoint.

wiki_catalogs.name: 功能开关系统
wiki_catalogs.prompt: 创建全面的功能开关系统文档。详细说明其目的、架构设计、实现细节、API接口、配置选项和集成模式。包括分层功能集合、多策略支持（简单、百分比、用户定向、时间、环境）、动态配置、中间件集成等内容。提供实际使用示例、最佳实践和故障排除指南。

wiki_catalogs.name: 功能开关API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: 创建全面的功能开关API文档。详细说明每个端点的用途、请求/响应结构、HTTP映射关系和使用示例。涵盖ListToggles、GetToggle、UpdateToggle、EnableToggle、DisableToggle、DeleteToggle、EvaluateToggle和GetStats等所有接口。

wiki_catalogs.name: 功能开关服务
wiki_catalogs.prompt: 创建功能开关服务的详细文档。说明其服务架构、核心组件（ToggleManager、策略引擎、文件仓库）、中间件集成方式和服务装饰器模式。包括各组件的交互关系和生命周期管理。

wiki_catalogs.name: Getting Started
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on onboarding new developers to the kratos-boilerplate project. Provide step-by-step instructions for setting up the development environment, including prerequisites like Go, Node.js, Docker, and Kratos CLI. Document the installation process using both direct execution and Docker-based workflows. Include a quick start tutorial that walks through cloning the repository, starting services via docker-compose, running the application, and accessing the frontend and API endpoints. Add troubleshooting tips for common setup issues like port conflicts, dependency installation failures, and database initialization problems. Reference the Makefile commands for building, testing, and running the application. Ensure the guide enables a developer to have a working instance within 10 minutes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dependency Injection with Wire
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content on the compile-time dependency injection system using Google Wire. Explain how Wire generates injector code in wire_gen.go based on provider sets defined in wire.go. Document the role of Injector interface in main.go and how components like server, service, and data are wired together without runtime reflection. Provide code examples showing provider functions for service, biz, and data layers. Explain benefits such as reduced startup time, compile-time safety, and improved testability. Address common issues like cyclic dependencies and missing providers, with troubleshooting guidance. Include best practices for organizing provider sets and scaling Wire usage in large services.

wiki_catalogs.name: Captcha Service
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Captcha Service in kratos-boilerplate. Explain the implementation of image, SMS, and email captcha generation and verification flows. Document the interaction between service, biz, and data layers, focusing on captcha storage, expiration, and validation logic. Include examples from captcha.go files showing how captchas are generated using the internal pkg and exposed via API endpoints. Describe the integration with external services for SMS/email delivery and the security considerations around captcha reuse and brute-force protection. Address common issues like captcha expiration, delivery failures, and accessibility concerns.

wiki_catalogs.name: Greeter API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed API documentation for the Greeter service defined in greeter.proto. Document the SayHello endpoint with its HTTP and gRPC interfaces, including request/response message structures. Explain the use of google.api.http annotations for HTTP/JSON mapping and error_reason.proto for error reporting. Provide examples of valid requests and responses in both JSON and protobuf formats. Describe the authentication requirements (if any) and how the service integrates with the overall security model. Include information on error codes, rate limiting, and monitoring considerations. Demonstrate usage patterns with client code examples in Go and TypeScript. Explain how this service serves as a reference implementation for creating new API services in the Kratos framework.

wiki_catalogs.name: Event Bus
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Event Bus system in kratos-boilerplate's plugin architecture. Explain how EventBus enables decoupled communication between core services and plugins using a publish-subscribe pattern. Document the definition of events in event.go, including event types and payload structures. Describe the implementation of EventBus in event_bus.go, including subscription management, event publishing, and asynchronous dispatching. Provide examples of how services emit events (e.g., user login, operation completed) and how plugins subscribe to them. Include code snippets demonstrating event registration and handler attachment. Address performance considerations like goroutine management, error handling in subscribers, and backpressure. Explain how the event bus supports extensibility while maintaining system stability.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Pinia-based state management system in the frontend application. Explain the design and structure of the auth store (auth.ts), including state properties (e.g., user, token), actions (login, logout, register), and getters. Describe how the store is initialized and injected into the Vue app via index.ts. Illustrate state flow during authentication processes with real code examples. Document best practices for handling asynchronous state updates, error states, and persistence. Address common challenges such as store hydration, race conditions, and debugging state changes using Vue DevTools.

wiki_catalogs.name: Migrations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the database migration system used in kratos-boilerplate. Explain the purpose and structure of each migration file, including the initial schema setup (000001_init_schema) and the KMS data keys table creation (000002_create_kms_data_keys). Document the up/down migration patterns, versioning strategy, and idempotency considerations. Provide examples of how to create, apply, and rollback migrations using the project's tooling. Describe the integration between the migration system and the application startup process. Include best practices for writing safe migrations in production environments, such as avoiding long-running transactions and handling data transformations incrementally. Address common issues like migration conflicts and failed rollbacks, and provide troubleshooting guidance.

wiki_catalogs.name: Sensitive Data Handling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the sensitive data protection system in kratos-boilerplate. Explain how the detector identifies PII and sensitive information using configurable rules and pattern matching. Describe the anonymization process that replaces sensitive data with masked or hashed values using the anonymizer and sanitizer components. Document the structured logger that ensures sensitive fields are automatically redacted in logs. Illustrate the middleware integration that applies detection and anonymization across service boundaries. Include examples from detector_test.go and rules_test.go showing detection patterns for common data types (emails, phone numbers, IDs). Explain how to extend the rules system for custom sensitive data types. Address performance implications and accuracy trade-offs in detection algorithms.

wiki_catalogs.name: Behavior-Driven Development (BDD) Testing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for BDD testing in kratos-boilerplate. Explain the Gherkin-style scenario design and how auth_bdd_test.go implements feature specifications using behavioral assertions. Document the shared test suite initialization in test_suite.go, including application bootstrapping and test database setup via docker-compose.test.yml. Describe the use of mocks.go for dependency isolation and consistent test state. Provide concrete examples from auth_bdd_test.go showing Given-When-Then test structure, HTTP request simulation, and response validation. Cover best practices for writing maintainable BDD tests, managing test data, and organizing test features by domain. Include execution workflow via run_tests.sh and integration with CI/CD pipelines.

wiki_catalogs.name: Plugin Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for plugin-specific configuration in kratos-boilerplate. Explain how plugins like audit_logger and auth_enhancer load their configuration from the configs/plugins/ directory. Document the structure and purpose of each plugin configuration file, including logging levels, event filters, and security policies. Describe how the plugin manager merges plugin configurations with the main application configuration and handles conflicts. Provide examples of configuring custom plugin behavior and validating plugin-specific settings. Include best practices for organizing plugin configurations and ensuring compatibility across plugin versions.

wiki_catalogs.name: docker-compose Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the docker-compose configurations in kratos-boilerplate. Compare and contrast the production (docker-compose.yml), development (docker-compose.dev.yml), and testing (test/config/docker-compose.test.yml) setups. Explain service definitions for the main application, PostgreSQL, Redis, and any supporting infrastructure. Document networking, volume mounting, environment variable injection, and dependency ordering. Provide guidance on extending configurations for staging environments, enabling/disabling plugins, and adjusting resource limits. Include examples of overriding settings for local development and troubleshooting common docker-compose issues such as container startup failures and network connectivity problems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Creating Services
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for creating new services using the Kratos framework. Walk through defining a new service contract in Protocol Buffers (e.g., greeter.proto), generating server stubs, and implementing the service in internal/service/. Explain how to register HTTP and gRPC routes via internal/server/http.go and grpc.go, including middleware integration. Use the Greeter service as a reference example. Document best practices for error handling using third_party/errors.proto, response formatting, and versioning API services. Show how to inject dependencies using Wire and connect the service to business use cases. Include examples of adding custom metadata, headers, and interceptors. Address common issues like endpoint not found errors and serialization problems.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Login
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for the User Login endpoint. Define the HTTP POST /auth/v1/login and corresponding gRPC method, detailing request parameters (username/email, password, captcha_token). Explain the authentication flow including credential validation, rate-limited login attempts, account lockout logic, and JWT token generation using golang-jwt/jwt. Document successful response with access_token and refresh_token, and error responses for invalid credentials, locked accounts, or missing captcha. Map error_reason.proto codes to HTTP 401, 403, and 429 statuses. Include examples of request/response payloads in JSON and protobuf formats. Describe integration with Redis for session state and captcha verification. Provide client-side examples in Go (gRPC) and TypeScript (fetch) showing proper header handling and token storage.

wiki_catalogs.name: Architecture & Design
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Clean Architecture implementation in kratos-boilerplate. Describe the four-layer architecture (API, Service, Biz, Data) and their responsibilities, dependency rules, and interaction patterns. Explain the role of Wire for compile-time dependency injection and show examples from wire.go and wire_gen.go. Document the Protocol Buffer-first design approach using .proto files to define API contracts. Detail the component interactions, data flows, and inversion of control principles. Include diagrams showing the dependency graph, request flow through middleware and service layers, and the dependency injection wiring. Address design trade-offs, scalability considerations, and how this architecture supports testability and maintainability.

wiki_catalogs.name: Protocol Buffer-First API Design
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Protocol Buffer-first API design approach used in kratos-boilerplate. Explain how .proto files in the api/ directory define both gRPC and HTTP/JSON APIs using google.api.http annotations. Document the workflow from proto definition to generated Go code and service implementation in internal/service/. Show how auth.proto defines Login, Register, and Refresh methods with request/response messages and maps to RESTful endpoints. Include examples of how proto messages are reused across services and how conf.proto defines configuration structure. Address how this design ensures API consistency, enables client SDK generation, and supports versioning. Provide guidelines for extending APIs and maintaining backward compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: Operation Logging
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Operation Logging system in kratos-boilerplate. Explain how audit logs are generated via middleware, stored in the database, and enriched with contextual information. Document the implementation in operation_log.go files across middleware, biz, and data layers, including the log structure and metadata collection. Describe integration with the plugin system through audit_logger.go and configuration via audit_logger.yaml. Include examples of log entries for key operations like login attempts and user modifications. Address performance considerations for high-volume logging, storage strategies, and querying capabilities. Provide troubleshooting guidance for missing logs or performance bottlenecks.

wiki_catalogs.name: Hook System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Hook System in kratos-boilerplate. Explain how HookManager orchestrates the execution of plugin-defined hooks at specific interception points in the application flow (e.g., pre-authentication, post-operation). Document the Hook interface and hook types defined in hook.go, and how plugins implement these to inject custom logic. Describe the registration and invocation mechanism in hook_manager.go, including ordering, error propagation, and timeout handling. Use real examples from auth_enhancer.go to show how hooks modify authentication behavior. Include guidance on creating synchronous vs. asynchronous hooks and best practices for error resilience. Address potential pitfalls like hook chaining failures, performance bottlenecks, and debugging hook execution order.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for frontend-backend API integration in kratos-boilerplate. Detail the implementation of request.ts as the HTTP client wrapper (likely using Axios or Fetch) with interceptors for authentication and error handling. Explain the auth.ts service methods (login, register, refresh) and their mapping to backend endpoints. Document the use of api.d.ts for TypeScript interfaces ensuring type safety. Provide usage examples for making authenticated requests, handling 401 redirects, and managing loading/error states. Include guidance on extending the API client for new endpoints and maintaining type consistency across frontend and backend contracts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Redis Usage
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for Redis integration in the kratos-boilerplate application. Explain its usage for session storage, captcha management, and temporary data caching. Document the configuration options in config.yaml related to Redis connectivity, including host, port, password, and database index. Describe the data structures used in Redis (strings, hashes, TTL-based expiration) and their purpose in the authentication flow. Provide code examples from the captcha and authentication modules showing how data is stored and retrieved. Address performance considerations, connection pooling, and error handling strategies when interacting with Redis. Include guidance on monitoring Redis memory usage and optimizing cache hit ratios. Discuss failover scenarios and resilience patterns when Redis is unavailable.

wiki_catalogs.name: Cryptographic Operations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the cryptographic operations in kratos-boilerplate. Detail the AES encryption implementation including key derivation, initialization vectors, and secure mode of operation. Explain the SM3 hash function usage for data integrity verification. Document how the KMS integrates with cryptographic services for secure key management and envelope encryption. Describe the crypto_service interface that abstracts cryptographic operations for plugin use. Include examples of encrypting sensitive payloads and generating secure hashes. Explain how the auth_enhancer plugin leverages these cryptographic primitives for enhanced authentication security. Address key rotation policies, secure storage practices, and compliance considerations for cryptographic implementations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Integration Testing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for integration testing in kratos-boilerplate. Focus on validating interactions between components, particularly between service, biz, and data layers with real database connectivity. Use auth_integration_test.go as a primary example to illustrate full-stack test execution from API call to database persistence. Explain how integration tests utilize PostgreSQL and Redis in containerized environments via docker-compose.test.yml. Document test setup and teardown procedures, transaction rollback strategies, and fixture data loading. Address configuration loading from config.yaml and its impact on test behavior. Provide guidance on testing error recovery, concurrency scenarios, and edge cases across service boundaries. Include execution commands and performance considerations for integration test suites.

wiki_catalogs.name: Environment Variables
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content on environment variable usage for configuration in kratos-boilerplate. Explain how environment variables can override settings in config.yaml and conf.proto-defined fields, particularly for deployment-specific values like database URLs, JWT secrets, and service endpoints. Document the naming convention for environment variables (e.g., uppercase with underscores) and how they map to nested configuration fields. Provide practical examples of setting environment variables in Docker, docker-compose, and Kubernetes environments. Include security considerations for managing secrets via environment variables and recommendations for using .env files in development versus secret managers in production.

wiki_catalogs.name: Production Considerations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create in-depth documentation covering production deployment considerations for kratos-boilerplate. Address critical aspects including environment variable management, secret handling (database credentials, JWT keys), logging configuration, and monitoring integration. Detail security hardening measures such as non-root containers, read-only filesystems, and network policies. Explain configuration best practices for high availability, connection pooling, and graceful shutdown. Cover scaling strategies, health check endpoints, and readiness/liveness probes. Provide recommendations for backup procedures, disaster recovery, and incident response planning in production environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Writing Tests
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for writing tests across all levels in the kratos-boilerplate. Explain unit testing business logic in internal/biz/ with mocks from internal/pkg/plugin/mock_repository.go. Cover BDD-style testing using auth_bdd_test.go with Ginkgo/Gomega patterns, including test suite setup in test/suite.go. Describe integration testing with real database connections using auth_integration_test.go and Docker-based test isolation. Demonstrate E2E testing of API endpoints via auth_e2e_test.go using api_client.go helpers. Show how to test service-layer behavior with mocked data layers. Include guidance on test data management, parallel execution, and coverage reporting. Address common issues like race conditions, flaky tests, and slow database setup.

wiki_catalogs.name: Refresh Token
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the Refresh Token endpoint. Specify the HTTP POST /auth/v1/refresh and gRPC method for renewing access tokens using a valid refresh token. Detail the request structure containing the refresh_token and optional device_id. Explain the server-side validation of refresh token signature, expiration, and revocation status stored in Redis. Document the response with a new access_token and optionally a renewed refresh_token based on rotation policy. Include error cases such as expired, revoked, or malformed tokens, mapped to appropriate error_reason codes and HTTP 401 status. Provide JSON and protobuf examples for request and response. Discuss security aspects like refresh token rotation, short expiration windows, and secure storage recommendations. Include implementation examples in Go and TypeScript demonstrating automatic token refresh in HTTP clients.

wiki_catalogs.name: Backend Services
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the core backend services in the kratos-boilerplate. Thoroughly explain the Authentication Service (registration, login, session management), Captcha Service (generation and verification), Operation Logging, and Sensitive Data Handling. For each service, document the implementation details across all layers (service, biz, data), invocation relationships, interfaces, domain models, and usage patterns. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase showing request handling, error management, and business logic execution. Explain relationships between services and shared components. Address common issues like authentication failures, captcha validation errors, and logging performance impacts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Sensitive Data Handling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Sensitive Data Handling system in kratos-boilerplate. Explain the automatic detection, anonymization, and secure logging of sensitive information (PII, credentials, etc.). Document the implementation of detection rules, anonymization strategies, and middleware integration that redacts sensitive data before logging. Include examples from anonymizer.go and rules.go showing pattern matching and masking techniques. Describe how the structured logger ensures compliance while maintaining debuggability. Address configuration of sensitivity rules, performance impact of real-time detection, and integration with the operation logging system. Provide guidance on extending detection rules for custom sensitive data types.

wiki_catalogs.name: Security Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Plugin Security Model in kratos-boilerplate. Explain how the system enforces a security sandbox for plugins through capability-based permissions defined in types.go (e.g., PluginPermissions, Capabilities). Document how plugin configuration in YAML files (audit_logger.yaml, auth_enhancer.yaml) controls access to sensitive operations and resources. Describe the principle of least privilege applied during plugin loading and execution. Provide examples of secure vs. insecure configuration patterns and how the system validates plugin permissions at runtime. Include guidance on designing secure plugins that minimize attack surface. Address common security concerns such as privilege escalation, configuration injection, and unsafe dependencies. Explain how the security model integrates with the overall application security posture.

wiki_catalogs.name: Routing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Vue Router configuration in the application. Explain the route definitions in index.ts, including path mappings to views (Home, Login, Register). Document the implementation of navigation guards for authentication protection (redirecting unauthenticated users from protected routes). Illustrate route meta fields usage for page titles or permissions. Provide examples of programmatic navigation and query parameter handling. Address common issues such as route lazy loading, scroll behavior, and dynamic route matching. Include best practices for route structure and SEO considerations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Key Management System (KMS) Design
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive architectural documentation for the Key Management System (KMS) in kratos-boilerplate. Describe the design principles behind the KMS, including root key and data key hierarchy, cryptographic envelope encryption, and secure key storage. Explain the implementation of the KMS manager, crypto service, and key lifecycle management. Document the interaction between the KMS and database for storing encrypted data keys. Detail the APIs for key generation, encryption, and decryption operations used by other components. Illustrate the data flow when encrypting sensitive information and retrieving keys for decryption. Address security considerations such as key rotation strategies, access control, and audit logging for key operations. Include performance implications of cryptographic operations and caching strategies for frequently used keys.

wiki_catalogs.name: Plugin System Security
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the plugin sandbox security model in kratos-boilerplate. Explain how the plugin manager enforces isolation and restricts plugin capabilities to prevent privilege escalation. Describe the hook system that allows plugins like auth_enhancer to extend functionality without direct access to core systems. Document the security boundaries and allowed interfaces defined in plugin/interfaces.go. Illustrate how configuration in auth_enhancer.yaml controls plugin behavior and access levels. Include examples showing how the auth_enhancer plugin securely integrates with the authentication flow to add additional verification steps. Address threat mitigation strategies for malicious plugins, including code signing, permission models, and runtime monitoring. Provide guidelines for developing secure plugins that follow least-privilege principles.

wiki_catalogs.name: End-to-End (E2E) Testing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for end-to-end testing in kratos-boilerplate. Explain how auth_e2e_test.go simulates real user workflows by interacting with the fully running application stack via HTTP API calls. Detail the use of api_client.go for request abstraction and test_user.go for managing test credentials and session state. Illustrate complete authentication flows including registration, login, token refresh, and protected endpoint access. Describe how E2E tests validate system behavior across frontend, backend, database, and external services. Cover environment setup using docker-compose.yml, service orchestration, and readiness checks. Include best practices for writing reliable E2E tests, handling flakiness, and structuring test scenarios. Discuss execution via run_tests.sh and reporting mechanisms.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration Best Practices
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content on configuration best practices for kratos-boilerplate deployments. Cover strategies for managing configuration across multiple environments (development, testing, staging, production) including file organization, version control practices, and secure handling of sensitive data. Discuss configuration validation techniques, schema versioning, and backward compatibility. Provide guidance on using configuration templates, automated linting, and pre-deployment checks. Include recommendations for monitoring configuration changes, auditing configuration drift, and implementing rollback procedures. Address performance implications of configuration loading and caching strategies for high-throughput services.

wiki_catalogs.name: Monitoring
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive monitoring documentation for kratos-boilerplate deployments. Explain how operation logging and structured logging (via sensitive package) enable observability. Document log format, levels, and sensitive data redaction mechanisms. Guide integration with monitoring systems (Prometheus, Grafana, ELK) by exposing metrics endpoints and configuring log aggregation. Detail key metrics to monitor (request latency, error rates, database performance) and recommended alerting thresholds. Provide examples of tracing request flows across services and diagnosing performance bottlenecks. Include strategies for log retention, rotation, and compliance with data protection regulations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Debugging
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for debugging the kratos-boilerplate application. Explain how to run the service in debug mode using Delve, set breakpoints in Go services, and inspect request flows through middleware like operation_log.go. Demonstrate using structured logging from structured_logger.go to trace sensitive data handling and audit operations. Show how to leverage the logchecker tool to validate log hygiene and detect information leaks. Include techniques for debugging gRPC calls with grpcurl, inspecting JWT tokens, and tracing plugin execution. Provide examples of diagnosing authentication failures, captcha mismatches, and database connection issues. Address performance debugging with pprof and identifying bottlenecks in cryptographic operations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Logout
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document the Logout endpoint in detail, including HTTP POST /auth/v1/logout and gRPC method. Explain the request structure requiring the current access_token and optional refresh_token for invalidation. Describe the server-side logic that adds tokens to a Redis-based denylist with TTL matching original expiration. Detail successful response with confirmation and error cases such as missing tokens or invalid format, returning appropriate error_reason codes and HTTP 400/401 statuses. Include JSON and protobuf payload examples. Discuss integration with session management and how logout affects concurrent sessions. Address security considerations like ensuring token revocation across distributed systems and preventing replay attacks. Provide client implementation examples in Go (gRPC interceptor cleanup) and TypeScript (clearing localStorage and calling logout API).

wiki_catalogs.name: API Reference
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for all public API endpoints defined in the kratos-boilerplate. For each API group (Authentication, Greeter), document the HTTP methods, URL patterns, request/response schemas, and authentication methods. Explain how gRPC services are mapped to RESTful endpoints using HTTP annotations in the .proto files. Include detailed request/response examples for each endpoint, showing JSON payloads and gRPC message structures. Document error handling strategies, status codes, and error_reason.proto usage. Address security considerations like JWT authentication, rate limiting, and input validation via validate.proto. Provide client implementation guidelines for both HTTP and gRPC consumers, including code examples in multiple languages if available.

wiki_catalogs.name: Plugin Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Plugin Configuration in kratos-boilerplate. Explain how plugins are configured through dedicated YAML files in the configs/plugins/ directory, using audit_logger.yaml and auth_enhancer.yaml as examples. Document the structure of these configuration files, including plugin metadata, enabled status, logging levels, and feature-specific parameters. Describe how the configuration is loaded and validated against the application's configuration schema defined in conf.proto. Provide examples of common configuration scenarios such as enabling/disabling plugins, adjusting timeouts, and setting up external service integrations. Include best practices for managing plugin configurations across environments (development, staging, production). Address configuration validation errors, hot-reload capabilities, and versioning considerations when updating plugin configurations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Security Best Practices
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive security best practices documentation for kratos-boilerplate deployments. Cover secure configuration management including environment variable handling, secret storage, and configuration file permissions. Detail audit logging configuration using the audit_logger plugin to track security-relevant events. Explain how to configure operation logging middleware for comprehensive activity tracking. Provide Docker security best practices such as minimal base images, non-root execution, and resource limits. Address network security considerations in docker-compose.yml including service isolation and port exposure. Include monitoring and alerting recommendations for detecting suspicious activities. Document secure deployment patterns for production environments, including TLS termination, WAF integration, and regular security patching. Provide checklists for security reviews and compliance audits.

wiki_catalogs.name: Test Automation and CI/CD Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for test automation and CI/CD integration in kratos-boilerplate. Explain how run_tests.sh orchestrates the execution of unit, BDD, integration, and E2E test suites in sequence or selectively. Document the role of setup.sh and teardown.sh in preparing and cleaning test environments, including database initialization and container lifecycle management. Describe how Makefile targets standardize test execution across development and CI environments. Illustrate the integration with GitHub Actions or similar CI systems using workflow configurations. Cover parallel test execution, log collection, coverage reporting, and failure notifications. Provide guidelines for extending the test pipeline, managing test secrets, and optimizing execution time in CI environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Plugin System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the plugin system in kratos-boilerplate. Explain the architecture of the extensible plugin framework, including dynamic loading, event-driven architecture with the event bus, and hook system for extending functionality. Document the security sandbox model and configuration options in plugin YAML files. Describe how to create, configure, and deploy custom plugins using the provided examples (audit_logger, auth_enhancer). Include implementation details from the plugin manager, hook manager, and interface definitions. Provide examples of common plugin use cases like audit logging, authentication enhancement, and custom business logic injection. Address potential issues like plugin conflicts, version compatibility, and performance overhead.

wiki_catalogs.name: Frontend Application
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the Vue.js frontend application in kratos-boilerplate. Describe the component architecture, including views, components, and reusable UI elements. Document the state management system using Pinia stores (auth.ts) and how application state is managed across authentication flows. Explain the routing configuration and navigation guards. Detail how the frontend integrates with backend APIs through the request.ts and auth.ts services. Include usage examples showing form handling, API calls, and state updates. Provide guidelines for responsive design, accessibility, and theming. Address common frontend issues like authentication state synchronization, error handling, and loading states.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the kratos-boilerplate system. Detail the database schema including the users table, data keys table, and any other entities defined in migration scripts. Document entity relationships, field definitions, data types, primary/foreign keys, indexes, and constraints. Explain the data access patterns through the Data layer and repository pattern implementation. Cover Redis usage for caching and session storage. Detail the Key Management System (KMS) design for cryptographic key generation and management. Include database schema diagrams, sample data, and queries. Address data lifecycle, retention policies, and security requirements for sensitive data storage.

wiki_catalogs.name: Security Considerations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive security documentation for kratos-boilerplate. Cover the authentication flow including JWT generation, validation, and token refresh mechanisms. Detail the sensitive data handling system that automatically detects and anonymizes personal information using the sensitive package. Explain the cryptographic operations provided by the crypto package (AES, SM3). Document the plugin sandbox security model and how auth_enhancer plugin extends authentication security. Address security best practices for configuration, secret management, and deployment. Include threat models for common attack vectors like brute force, XSS, and data leakage. Provide guidance on security monitoring and audit logging configuration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Testing Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the testing strategy in kratos-boilerplate. Document the multi-layered testing approach including unit tests, BDD tests using Gherkin-style scenarios, integration tests with database fixtures, and end-to-end tests. Explain the test organization in the test/ directory and how different test types are executed via run_tests.sh and Makefile commands. Provide examples of test implementations from auth_bdd_test.go and auth_integration_test.go showing test setup, execution, and verification patterns. Address test coverage analysis, mocking strategies using mock_test.go, and test data management. Include guidelines for writing new tests and debugging test failures. Discuss CI/CD integration and test automation considerations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the configuration system in kratos-boilerplate. Document the main configuration file (config.yaml) structure, fields, and their meanings as defined in conf.proto. Explain how configuration is loaded and validated at application startup. Detail the plugin-specific configuration in the plugins/ directory and how these are merged with the main configuration. Cover environment variable overrides and configuration for different deployment environments (development, testing, production). Provide best practices for securing sensitive configuration values, managing configuration across environments, and validating configuration changes. Include examples of common configuration scenarios and troubleshooting tips for configuration-related issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: Deployment
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive deployment documentation for kratos-boilerplate. Detail the Docker-based deployment process using the provided Dockerfile and docker-compose configurations. Explain the differences between production (docker-compose.yml) and development (docker-compose.dev.yml) setups. Document the build process via Makefile commands and container orchestration requirements. Cover production considerations such as environment variables, secret management, logging, monitoring, and scaling. Provide guidance on deploying to different environments (local, staging, production) and cloud platforms. Address zero-downtime deployment strategies, health checks, and rollback procedures. Include performance tuning recommendations and resource requirements.

wiki_catalogs.name: Development Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create a comprehensive development guide for extending the kratos-boilerplate. Provide step-by-step instructions for common development tasks: adding new features, creating new services, defining API endpoints with Protocol Buffers, and implementing business logic. Explain the workflow for generating code with Wire (wire_gen.go) and Kratos tools. Document best practices for writing maintainable code that follows the Clean Architecture principles. Include debugging techniques, logging strategies, and performance profiling methods. Provide examples of extending existing functionality and creating new endpoints. Address code organization standards and how to maintain consistency with the existing codebase.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Analysis of Kratos Boilerplate Project

## 1. Project Introduction

The Kratos Boilerplate project is a comprehensive Go-based backend service template built on the Kratos framework. This project serves as a production-ready foundation for building microservices with robust authentication, security, and extensibility features. The core goals include providing a standardized architecture for authentication services, implementing comprehensive security measures including sensitive data handling, and offering an extensible plugin system for modular functionality.

The target audience includes Go developers building microservices, backend engineers requiring robust authentication systems, and teams looking for a well-structured boilerplate to accelerate development. The project demonstrates best practices in Go microservice architecture, including proper separation of concerns, comprehensive testing strategies, and modern DevOps practices.

## 2. Technical Architecture

The project follows a clean architecture pattern with clear separation between components. The system is organized into distinct layers including API definitions, business logic, data access, and service implementations.

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client] --> B[HTTP/gRPC API]
    B --> C[Service Layer]
    C --> D[Biz Layer]
    D --> E[Data Layer]
    E --> F[(Database)]
    E --> G[(Redis)]
    H[Plugins] --> C
    I[Frontend] --> B
    J[Config] --> C
    K[Middleware] --> C
```

The architecture implements the Dependency Injection pattern through Wire, with components wired together in a predictable manner. The project uses Protocol Buffers for API definition, enabling both gRPC and HTTP/JSON interfaces from the same contract. This approach ensures consistency across different transport layers while maintaining type safety.

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
The application entry point is located at `cmd/kratos-boilerplate/main.go`, which initializes the application with configuration, logging, and dependency injection. The main function orchestrates the startup process by loading configuration, setting up logging, and initializing the application through Wire-generated code.

### Core Modules
The core modules are organized in the `internal` directory with a clear separation of concerns:
- **biz**: Contains business logic and use cases
- **data**: Handles data persistence and storage operations
- **service**: Implements the service layer that connects business logic with transport protocols
- **pkg**: Provides reusable utility packages for captcha, crypto, KMS, plugins, and sensitive data handling

### Configuration Approach
Configuration is managed through YAML files in the `configs` directory, with support for environment-specific configurations. The main configuration file `configs/config.yaml` defines server settings, database connections, and plugin configurations. The project uses Kratos' config package to load and parse configuration from files.

### External Dependencies
The project relies on several key external dependencies:
- **go-kratos/kratos**: Framework for building microservices
- **google/wire**: Compile-time dependency injection
- **lib/pq**: PostgreSQL driver
- **redis/go-redis**: Redis client
- **golang-jwt/jwt**: JWT token handling
- **golang.org/x/crypto**: Cryptographic functions

### Integration Points
Key integration points include:
- **Database**: PostgreSQL for persistent storage
- **Redis**: For caching and temporary data storage
- **Plugins**: Extensible plugin system for adding functionality
- **Frontend**: Vue.js application that consumes the API

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Frontend] --> B[HTTP API]
    B --> C[AuthService]
    C --> D[AuthUsecase]
    D --> E[UserRepo]
    E --> F[PostgreSQL]
    D --> G[CaptchaService]
    G --> H[Redis]
    I[Plugins] --> C
```

## 4. Key Features

### Authentication System
The project implements a comprehensive authentication system with features including user registration, login, logout, token refresh, and account locking. The system uses JWT for token-based authentication with access and refresh tokens, providing secure session management.

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> Registering: Register Request
    Idle --> LoggingIn: Login Request
    LoggingIn --> Locked: Failed Attempts > Max
    LoggingIn --> Authenticated: Valid Credentials
    Authenticated --> Refreshing: Token Refresh
    Authenticated --> LoggedOut: Logout
    LoggedOut --> Idle: Complete
    Locked --> Idle: Lock Duration Expired
```

### Sensitive Data Handling
The project includes a sophisticated system for handling sensitive data through the `internal/pkg/sensitive` package. This feature automatically detects and anonymizes sensitive information in logs and responses, protecting user privacy and complying with data protection regulations.

### Plugin System
An extensible plugin system allows for runtime loading of additional functionality. The system supports plugin security features like sandboxing and resource limits, ensuring that plugins cannot compromise the main application.

### Comprehensive Testing
The project implements a hybrid testing strategy combining TDD for unit testing and BDD for integration testing. This approach ensures both code quality at the unit level and correct behavior at the business logic level.

Sources:
- [README.md](README.md)
- [main.go](cmd/kratos-boilerplate/main.go)
- [biz.go](internal/biz/biz.go)
- [data.go](internal/data/data.go)
- [http.go](internal/server/http.go)
- [auth.go](internal/service/auth.go)
- [auth.go](internal/biz/auth.go)
- [README.md](internal/pkg/sensitive/README.md)
- [config.yaml](configs/config.yaml)
</blog>
